qas.question: How is diagnosis of infectious disease almost always initiated?

answers.text: by medical history and physical examination

qas.question: What does taking a culture of an infectious agent isolated from a patient allow?
What features of an infectious organism does a culture allow examining?
What can organisms be directly identified by?
What technique can be used to produce images of internal abnormalities?

answers.text: X-rays, CAT scans, PET scans or NMR

plausible_answers.text: by medical history and physical examination

qas.question: How is diagnosis of infectious disease rarely initiated?
What does taking a culture of an infectious agent isolated from a patient restrict?
What features of an infectious organism does a culture forbid examining?
What can organisms never be directly identified by?

plausible_answers.text: X-rays, CAT scans, PET scans or NMR

qas.question: What technique can be used to produce images of external abnormalities?

context: Diagnosis of infectious disease is nearly always initiated <a0_0><b5_0>by medical history and physical examination<b5_0/><a0_0/>. More <a1_0><b6_0>detailed identification<b6_0/><a1_0/> techniques involve the culture of infectious agents isolated from a patient. Culture allows identification of infectious organisms by examining their <a2_0><b7_0>microscopic features<b7_0/><a2_0/>, by detecting the presence of substances produced by pathogens, and by directly identifying an organism by <a3_0><b8_0>its genotype<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Other techniques (such as <a4_0><b9_0>X-rays, CAT scans, PET scans or NMR<b9_0/><a4_0/>) are used to produce images of internal abnormalities resulting from the growth of an infectious agent. The images are useful in detection of, for example, a bone abscess or a spongiform encephalopathy produced by a prion.
